newsitem.title: USA: Burlington revenues off on corn export drop.
newsitem.headline: Burlington revenues off on corn export drop.

text.p: Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp Tuesday reported a four percent increase in third quarter net income to $247 million, or $1.58 per share, on a two percent decline in revenues to $2.05 billion.

Agricultural commodities revenues declined $100 million or 30 percent due to a significant decline in corn exports, compared with record corn and wheat exports a year ago, the railroad said. Among other major sectors, coal revenues increased five percent to $520 million, chemicals revenues increased eight percent to $190 million and intermodal revenues increased two percent to $529 million.

"Our 1996 third quarter performance beat last year's record quarterly results, even with a $100 million shortfall in agricultural commodities revenues," said chief executive Robert D. Krebs. "This demonstrates the value of our commodity balance and tight expense controls."

Third quarter 1996 operating expenses were $1.57 billion, $54 million below 1995. Compensation and benefits expense declined $23 million to $633 million, due to a lower number of salaried employees as a result of the September 1995 merger of the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe railroads.
The expense reductions were partially offset by increases in fuel, equipment rents and depreciation and amortization expenses, Burlington said.
